articles.headline: New Fashion Runway: Wall Street
articles.snippet: Michael Kors had extraordinary success with an initial public offering of his brand nearly two years ago, leading other designers to consider the same.
articles.abstract: Michael Kors had extraordinary success with an initial public offering of his brand nearly two years ago, leading other designers to consider the same.
articles.lead_paragraph: With his red-carpet gowns, lush cashmere sweaters and jet-set shoulder totes, Michael Kors has influenced fellow designers across the globe.

articles.headline: In Rural Iowa, Spending, Not the Shutdown, Raises Worry
articles.snippet: While Representative Steve King’s constituents are beginning to question his tactics and his focus on the health law, they support his core commitment to cutting the size of government.
articles.abstract: While Representative Steve King’s constituents are beginning to question his tactics and his focus on the health law, they support his core commitment to cutting the size of government.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Republican Party has long claimed to be the champion of business, large and small, and an advocate for fiscal responsibility. Yet now Republicans in Congress have precipitated a shutdown of the federal government and are threatening to let the nation default on its once Triple-A-rated debt.

articles.headline: Questions Often Asked About Health Law
articles.snippet: In the first week of the Obama administration’s health care enrollment period, consumers had questions on insuring dependent children over 26 years old, immigrants and pre-existing conditions.
articles.abstract: In the first week of the Obama administration’s health care enrollment period, consumers had questions on insuring dependent children over 26 years old, immigrants and pre-existing conditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Millions of consumers rushed to the online health care exchanges on Tuesday only to be greeted with long waits and frustrating error messages.

articles.headline: Upstart Abu Dhabi Airline Becomes Ally to European Carriers
articles.snippet: Flush with Abu Dhabi’s wealth, the government-owned Etihad Airlines has emerged as a go-to financier in Europe for struggling rivals, helping raise its global profile.
articles.abstract: Flush with Abu Dhabi’s wealth, the government-owned Etihad Airlines has emerged as a go-to financier in Europe for struggling rivals, helping raise its global profile.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — Just a few years ago, James Hogan, the chief executive of Etihad Airways, probably would have had trouble scoring a meeting with one of his European counterparts. These days, however, it seems he’s never been so popular.

articles.headline: Boehner Urges G.O.P. Unity in ‘Epic Battle’
articles.snippet: Speaker John A. Boehner offered no clue on Friday as to how he expected Congress to get out of the dead end it has found itself in, with the government shut for a fourth day.
articles.abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner offered no clue on Friday as to how he expected Congress to get out of the dead end it has found itself in, with the government shut for a fourth day.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With his troops anxious for a way forward, Speaker John A. Boehner began a closed-door meeting of House Republicans on Friday morning with a recitation of letters from local schoolchildren on how they deal with stress.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Curtain Is Rising on a Tech Premiere With (as Usual) a Mostly Male Cast
articles.snippet: Even as women make headway in fields like law and business, and technology zooms along as one of the fastest-growing sectors of the economy, its doors remain virtually closed to women.
articles.abstract: Even as women make headway in fields like law and business, and technology zooms along as one of the fastest-growing sectors of the economy, its doors remain virtually closed to women.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Twitter’s financial filing for its Wall Street debut was chock-full of juicy tidbits, from the name of its richest founder to a list of its escalating losses. But one revelation was particularly startling: Just a single woman among its top officials.

articles.headline: What Can Be Sold in 140 Characters? That’s Now the Challenge for Twitter
articles.snippet: In documents filed on Thursday, Twitter noted that it has been greatly expanding its inventory of advertising slots, especially for promoted tweets.
articles.abstract: In documents filed on Thursday, Twitter noted that it has been greatly expanding its inventory of advertising slots, especially for promoted tweets.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Once Twitter enters life as a publicly traded company, it will have to satisfy Wall Street’s demands for constant growth.

articles.headline: Deciding Who Sees Students’ Data
articles.snippet: Schools across the country are looking at new online ways to integrate and analyze information about their students. But privacy advocates remain wary.
articles.abstract: Schools across the country are looking at new online ways to integrate and analyze information about their students. But privacy advocates remain wary.
articles.lead_paragraph: WHEN Cynthia Stevenson, the superintendent of Jefferson County, Colo., public schools, heard about a data repository called inBloom, she thought it sounded like a technological fix for one of her bigger headaches. Over the years, the Jeffco school system, as it is known, which lies west of Denver, had invested in a couple of dozen student data systems, many of which were incompatible.

articles.headline: U.S. Raids in Libya and Somalia Strike Terror Targets
articles.snippet: American troops assisted by the F.B.I. and C.I.A. seized a militant in Tripoli who was indicted for his role in the 1998 embassy bombings, and Navy SEALs attacked a villa in a Somali town known as a militant hub.
articles.abstract: American troops assisted by the F.B.I. and C.I.A. seized a militant in Tripoli who was indicted for his role in the 1998 embassy bombings, and Navy SEALs attacked a villa in a Somali town known as a militant hub.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — American commandos carried out raids on Saturday in two far-flung African countries in a powerful flex of military muscle aimed at capturing fugitive terrorist suspects. American troops assisted by F.B.I. and C.I.A. agents seized a suspected leader of Al Qaeda on the streets of Tripoli, Libya, while Navy SEALs raided the seaside villa of a militant leader in a predawn firefight on the coast of Somalia.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick, Nicholas Kulish and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: At the S.E.C., a Question of Home-Court Edge
articles.snippet: S.E.C. tribunals are  likely to become busier under the Dodd-Frank law, but some legal experts see a  potential for bias because the judges operate within the agency bringing the cases.
articles.abstract: S.E.C. tribunals are  likely to become busier under the Dodd-Frank law, but some legal experts see a  potential for bias because the judges operate within the agency bringing the cases.
articles.lead_paragraph: SINCE Mary Jo White settled in as chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, lots of tough talk has emanated from the agency about enforcement priorities. Just last week, Andrew Ceresney, co-director of enforcement, told an audience in New York to expect bolder actions out of the agency, especially when it comes to penalizing individuals.

articles.headline: Mugged by a Mug Shot Online
articles.snippet: Web sites are publishing arrest photos of millions of Americans and often charging fees to remove the pictures.
articles.abstract: Web sites are publishing arrest photos of millions of Americans and often charging fees to remove the pictures.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN March last year, a college freshman named Maxwell Birnbaum was riding in a van filled with friends from Austin, Tex., to a spring-break rental house in Gulf Shores, Ala. As they neared their destination, the police pulled the van over, citing a faulty taillight. When an officer asked if he could search the vehicle, the driver — a fraternity brother of Mr. Birnbaum’s who quickly regretted his decision — said yes.

articles.headline: As Germans Push Austerity, Greeks Press Nazi-Era Claims
articles.snippet: Resentment over Germany’s power to dictate budget austerity to Greece has some Greeks talking about settling debts from World War II.
articles.abstract: Resentment over Germany’s power to dictate budget austerity to Greece has some Greeks talking about settling debts from World War II.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMIRAS, Greece — As they moved through the isolated villages in this region in 1943, systematically killing men in a reprisal for an attack on a small outpost, German soldiers dragged Giannis Syngelakis’s father from his home here and shot him in the head. Within two days, more than 400 men were dead and the women left behind struggled with the monstrous task of burying so many corpses.

articles.headline: Karzai Is Planning to Be There for a Successor. Right There.
articles.snippet: Hamid Karzai, Afghanistan’s president, is moving next door to the presidential palace after his final term ends, and he seems eager to exert influence over his successor.
articles.abstract: Hamid Karzai, Afghanistan’s president, is moving next door to the presidential palace after his final term ends, and he seems eager to exert influence over his successor.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — With less than a year left in his final term, President Hamid Karzai insists that he is eager to leave the presidential palace and lead a quieter life. It turns out, though, he may just be moving next door, to a lavish new home yards from the complex that has been the seat of his power for more than a decade.

articles.headline: Selling Secrets of Phone Users to Advertisers
articles.snippet: Advertisers and tech companies are finding new ways to track us on our smartphones and reach us with individualized ads.
articles.abstract: Advertisers and tech companies are finding new ways to track us on our smartphones and reach us with individualized ads.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Once, only hairdressers and bartenders knew people’s secrets.
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: A Federal Budget Crisis Months in the Planning
articles.snippet: The stand by conservatives that led to the current crisis was the outgrowth of a long-running effort, waged by a galaxy of well-funded groups, to undo President Obama’s health care law.
articles.abstract: The stand by conservatives that led to the current crisis was the outgrowth of a long-running effort, waged by a galaxy of well-funded groups, to undo President Obama’s health care law.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Shortly after President Obama started his second term, a loose-knit coalition of conservative activists led by former Attorney General Edwin Meese III gathered in the capital to plot strategy. Their push to repeal Mr. Obama’s health care law was going nowhere, and they desperately needed a new plan.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Mike McIntire

articles.headline: Libya Condemns U.S. for Seizing Terror Suspect
articles.snippet: A day after American commandos carried out raids in two African countries, Libya’s interim government demanded an explanation from Washington for what it called the “kidnapping” of a Libyan suspect.
articles.abstract: A day after American commandos carried out raids in two African countries, Libya’s interim government demanded an explanation from Washington for what it called the “kidnapping” of a Libyan suspect.
articles.lead_paragraph: TRIPOLI, Libya — Libya’s fragile interim government condemned the United States on Sunday for what it called the “kidnapping of a Libyan citizen” from this capital city a day earlier, and Libyan lawmakers threatened to remove the prime minister if the government was involved.
articles.byline: By Carlotta Gall and David D. Kirkpatrick

articles.headline: U.S. Said to Hold Qaeda Suspect on Navy Ship
articles.snippet: With the capture of Abu Anas al-Libi, only a few Qaeda operatives indicted in the 1998 bombings of two American embassies in East Africa are believed to be still at large.
articles.abstract: With the capture of Abu Anas al-Libi, only a few Qaeda operatives indicted in the 1998 bombings of two American embassies in East Africa are believed to be still at large.
articles.lead_paragraph: An accused operative for Al Qaeda seized by United States commandos in Libya over the weekend is being interrogated while in military custody on a Navy ship in the Mediterranean Sea, officials said on Sunday. He is expected eventually to be sent to New York for criminal prosecution.
articles.byline: By Benjamin Weiser and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Swarm of Rivals Seeking Share of Social Media Pie
articles.snippet: Ahead of its I.P.O., Twitter must  prove it can fend off a younger generation of nimble social services that offer clever new ways for people to connect and share.
articles.abstract: Ahead of its I.P.O., Twitter must  prove it can fend off a younger generation of nimble social services that offer clever new ways for people to connect and share.
articles.lead_paragraph: Twitter, poised to make its splashy entrance on Wall Street, has helped define modern social networking. But while seeking to establish itself as an Internet powerhouse, it must also prove it can fend off a rising threat from a younger generation of nimble social outlets that offer clever new ways for people to connect and share content.
articles.byline: By Jenna Wortham and Vindu Goel

articles.headline: Europe Aims to Regulate the Cloud
articles.snippet: Legislators are pushing for privacy protections, even if using cloud technology becomes more complicated as a result.
articles.abstract: Legislators are pushing for privacy protections, even if using cloud technology becomes more complicated as a result.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — The words “cloud computing” never appeared in a 119-page digital privacy regulation introduced in Europe last year.

articles.headline: At a Nissan Plant in Mississippi, a Battle to Shape the U.A.W.’s Future
articles.snippet: The United Automobile Workers is taking a campaign global to promote a unionization effort at Nissan’s plant in Canton, Miss.
articles.abstract: The United Automobile Workers is taking a campaign global to promote a unionization effort at Nissan’s plant in Canton, Miss.
articles.lead_paragraph: CANTON, Miss. — The United Automobile Workers — desperate to make inroads in the anti-union South where Toyota, Volkswagen and other foreign automakers have assembly plants — has never tried a unionization drive quite like the one at the Nissan plant here.

articles.headline: Using Twitter to Move the Markets
articles.snippet: Over the course of three Twitter posts about Apple from the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, the company’s market capitalization rose about $17 billion.
articles.abstract: Over the course of three Twitter posts about Apple from the activist investor Carl C. Icahn, the company’s market capitalization rose about $17 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week, while everyone was wondering what Twitter is worth after the unveiling of its I.P.O., I spent some time on a little different math. How much could a single post on Twitter be worth?

articles.headline: As DVRs Shift TV Habits, Ratings Calculations Follow
articles.snippet: What is notable about the start of the new fall TV season, according to network executives, is a surge in not just delayed viewing, but very-delayed viewing.
articles.abstract: What is notable about the start of the new fall TV season, according to network executives, is a surge in not just delayed viewing, but very-delayed viewing.
articles.lead_paragraph: One day after Fox introduced the Headless Horseman drama “Sleepy Hollow” last month, the television world was impressed by its overnight rating, a 3.4 among adults age 18 to 49. Fox knew it would grow: based on last season’s viewing trends, Fox figured the premiere episode would finish between a 5.1 and a 5.4 rating once seven days of digital video recorder playback were added.

articles.headline: Fed Up on the Prairie, and Voting on Seceding From Colorado
articles.snippet: In November, 11 rural counties will hold a vote on whether to secede from the state and work to form their own — or maybe join Wyoming.
articles.abstract: In November, 11 rural counties will hold a vote on whether to secede from the state and work to form their own — or maybe join Wyoming.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHEYENNE WELLS, Colo. — The Old West has decided it is fed up with the New West.

articles.headline: Give Us This Day, Our Daily Senate Scolding
articles.snippet: Since the government shutdown, Barry C. Black, the Senate chaplain, has turned the morning invocation into a daily conscience check.
articles.abstract: Since the government shutdown, Barry C. Black, the Senate chaplain, has turned the morning invocation into a daily conscience check.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The disapproval comes from angry constituents, baffled party elders and colleagues on the other side of the Capitol. But nowhere have senators found criticism more personal or immediate than right inside their own chamber every morning when the chaplain delivers the opening prayer.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Has Deep Docket in Its New Term
articles.snippet: Affirmative action, abortion, public prayer and campaign contributions are among the issues to be addressed, with chances for the justices to reverse consequential precedents.
articles.abstract: Affirmative action, abortion, public prayer and campaign contributions are among the issues to be addressed, with chances for the justices to reverse consequential precedents.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After back-to-back terms ending in historic rulings that riveted the nation, the Supreme Court might have been expected to return to its usual diet of routine cases that rarely engage the public.

articles.headline: Egyptian Attacks Are Escalating Amid Stalemate
articles.snippet: The lethal conflict between Egypt’s military-backed government and its Islamist opponents grew on Monday, with an expansion of attacks against government targets.
articles.abstract: The lethal conflict between Egypt’s military-backed government and its Islamist opponents grew on Monday, with an expansion of attacks against government targets.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The lethal conflict between Egypt’s military-backed government and its Islamist opponents escalated on Monday, with an expansion of attacks against government targets, signs that the authorities have failed to secure the streets and that both sides refuse to back down.
